body_html:
What would be the output for the second example if we change the input data:

a = torch.tensor([[1, 0, 2], [1, 0, 0], [2, 3, 3]])
torch.unique(a, dim=1)
> tensor([[0, 1, 2], [0, 1], [2,3]])

This would create a tensor with different sizes in the dimensions.
Numpy has an axis argument, but removes duplicated items along the provided axis, as shown in your first example.
body_text:
What would be the output for the second example if we change the input data:
a = torch.tensor([[1, 0, 2], [1, 0, 0], [2, 3, 3]])
torch.unique(a, dim=1)
> tensor([[0, 1, 2], [0, 1], [2,3]])
This would create a tensor with different sizes in the dimensions.
Numpy has an axis argument, but removes duplicated items along the provided axis, as shown in your first example.
body:
What would be the output for the second example if we change the input data:
```python
a = torch.tensor([[1, 0, 2], [1, 0, 0], [2, 3, 3]])
torch.unique(a, dim=1)
> tensor([[0, 1, 2], [0, 1], [2,3]])
```
This would create a `tensor` with different sizes in the dimensions.
[Numpy](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.14.0/reference/generated/numpy.unique.html) has an `axis` argument, but removes duplicated items along the provided axis, as shown in your first example.
